{"seo": [], "title": "Simba Points", "blocks": [{"id": "m2vlzqin", "type": "country_banner", "enabled": true, "enable_subtitle": true, "enable_cta_button": false, "country_banner_image": "simba-points-detail-bg.jpg", "country_banner_title": "Simba Points", "country_banner_subtitle": "KCB Rewards"}, {"id": "m3htg7xz", "type": "custom_content", "enabled": true, "custom_content_text": "

About Simba Points

Welcome to KCB Simba Points

KCB Simba Points is a loyalty program that rewards you for simply "banking with us". Every time you transact with your credit or debit card, use KCB Mobile banking to pay bills, purchase airtime or transfer funds to a KCB account on *522# or our KCB App, bank online with KCB iBANK, transact at any KCB Bank Agent, secure a personal loan or mortgage, KCB rewards you.

Why join KCB Simba Points?

Joining KCB Simba Loyalty program is fast, easy and FREE. KCB will reward you for your everyday transactions, and you can redeem your points for cash and airtime any time you need it.

How To Earn Points

EARN SIMBA POINTS

The KCB Simba Points program allows you to earn points every time you transact with your credit or debit card, use KCB Mobile banking to pay bills, purchase airtime or transfer funds to a KCB account on *522# or our KCB App, bank online with KCB iBANK, transact at any KCB Bank Agent, secure a personal loan or mortgage.

The earned points can be redeemed for cash and airtime. Start earning your KCB Simba Points now by using any of the transactions listed below. And remember, the more you transact, the more points you earn and the quicker you redeem for great rewards absolutely free.

HOW TO JOIN/ENROL

Enrollment on Mobi USSD *522# The Customer can enroll for Simba Points by following the following steps.
  • Dial *522#.
  • Select My Account.
  • Select Simba Points .
  • Accept Terms and Conditions.
  • Enroll.
Enrollment on the App

The customer can enroll for Simba Points by following the following steps.

  • Download the KCB App on App Store
  • Go to the main menu on the top left-hand side click on the 3 lines to access the drawer menu.
  • Select Simba Points .
  • Enter the 5-digit mobile banking PIN.
  • Select Enroll.

HOW TO REDEEM

Redeem Cash on USSD *522# by following the following step:
  • Dial *522#.
  • Select My Account.
  • Select Simba Points.
  • Select Redeem Cash.
  • Select Account where the funds will be credited.
  • Enter the number of points to redeem.
  • Enter the 5-digit mobile banking PIN.
  • Confirm the information and submit.
Redeem Cash on KCB App
  • Download the KCB App on App Store
  • Go to the main menu on the top left hand side click on the 3 lines to access the drawer menu.
  • Select Simba Points.
  • Enter the 5-digit mobile banking PIN.
  • Select cash.
  • Enter the number of points to redeem.
  • Confirm the details and select proceed.
  • Enter the 5*digit mobile banking pin again.
  • Enter the 4-digit authorization code and submit.
  • Select Enroll.
Redeem Airtime on USSD *522# by following the following steps:
  • Dial *522#.
  • Select My Account.
  • Select Simba Points.
  • Select Redeem Airtime.
  • Select your account.
  • Select Airtime Operator.
  • Select the number of points to redeem.
  • Enter recipient's mobile number.
  • Enter the 5-digit mobile banking PIN.
  • Confirm the information and submit.
Redeem Airtime on KCB App by following the following steps:
  • Download the KCB App on App Store
  • Go to the main menu on the top left hand side click on the 3 lines to access the drawer menu
  • Select Simba Points.
  • Enter the 5-digit mobile banking PIN.
  • Select airtime.
  • Enter the mobile number to receive the airtime.
  • Select the telecommunication service provider (Safaricom/Airtel/Telcom).
  • Enter amount of points to redeem for airtime.
  • Select Submit.
  • Confirm details and proceed.
  • Enter the 5-digit mobile banking PIN.
  • The airtime will be credited to the mobile number.

HOW TO CHECK BALANCE

Check balance on USSD *522# by following the following steps:
  • Dial *522#.
  • Select My Account.
  • Select Simba Points.
  • Select Check Points.
  • Select your account.
  • Enter the Mobile Banking Pin.
  • You will receive an SMS notification with your points balance.
Check balance on KCB App by following the following steps:
  • Download the KCB App on App Store.
  • Go to the main menu on the top left hand side click on the 3 lines to access the drawer menu.
  • Select Simba Points.
  • Enter the 5-digit mobile banking PIN.
  • The points balance will be displayed in the home page of your Simba Points profile.
"}], "footer": "footers/main_footer", "header": "headers/country", "parent": "1592", "updated_by": 3, "header_logo": null, "override_logo": false, "page_sections": null, "bottom_bar_nav": null, "duplicated_from": 6341}

{"seo": [], "title": "Murabahah", "blocks": [{"id": "m3as479m", "type": "country_banner", "enabled": true, "enable_subtitle": true, "enable_cta_button": false, "country_banner_image": "kenya/sahl/sahl-simba-savings-account-banner-1726163232.jpg", "country_banner_title": "Financing Contracts", "country_banner_subtitle": "Murabahah"}, {"id": "m3aqvp1e", "type": "content_card", "enabled": true, "content_card_text": "Murabahah is the sale of a commodity for the price at which the seller has purchased it, with the addition of a stated profit known to the buyer. The only features distinguish it from other kind of sale is that the seller expressly tells the purchaser how much cost he has incurred and how much profit he is going to charge in addition to the cost. If a person sells a commodity without reference to the cost, this is not murabahah.", "content_card_title": "Definition"}, {"id": "m3arjuv4", "type": "content_card", "enabled": true, "content_card_text": "
  • Islamic financial principles are premised on the principle of providing for the welfare of the population by prohibiting practices considered unfair or exploitative.
  • The Islamic financial system strictly prohibits giving or receiving of any fixed or predetermined rate of return on financial transactions-interest.
    • ", "content_card_title": "Murabahah"}, {"id": "m3arp31h", "type": "content_card", "enabled": true, "content_card_text": "
  • Several contracts are completed in steps.
  • The sequence of their execution is key to making the transactions shariah compliant.
  • The mark-up (profit) may be an absolute amount or a percentage of the cost price.
  • Since it is a ‘sale’ the contract price (cost + profit) cannot be varied during the tenure of the facility.
  • Even if the customer repays the facility at any time before agreed tenure the bank is contractually entitled to full outstanding amount but may choose Rebate which is at the discretion of the bank. It is not contractual.

    • If the facility is restructured, say extension of repayment period, the bank cannot charge additional profit for the extended period.

    ", "content_card_title": "Features of Murabahah"}, {"id": "m3arufib", "type": "content_card", "enabled": true, "content_card_text": "
  • Having identified the asset.
  • The customer approaches the Bank and gives a unilateral undertaking to purchase the Asset.
  • If the customer qualifies, the Bank and customer enter a Murabahah financing agreement (Execution of Master Murabahah Agreement).
  • The bank appoints the customer as its agent to buy the assets/goods from the supplier (Agency agreement is executed).
  • Goods are purchased by the Bank via its agent (client) and liability is assumed by the bank.
  • The bank accepts the customer’s offer.
  • Client purchases the goods from the bank and repays the contract price (cost + mark-up) according to the agreed repayment terms.

    • NB: A reminder that funds for financing under Murabahah contract should not be accessed by the customers but remitted directly to the vendors/beneficiaries as per proforma invoice provided at application stage.

    ", "content_card_title": "Steps in Murabahah"}], "footer": "footers/main_footer", "header": "headers/sahl", "parent": "1592", "updated_by": 15, "header_logo": "kenya/sahl-logo.jpg", "override_logo": true, "page_sections": null, "bottom_bar_nav": null}

{"seo": [], "title": "Musharakah", "blocks": [{"id": "m3as3bwh", "type": "country_banner", "enabled": true, "enable_subtitle": true, "enable_cta_button": false, "country_banner_image": "kenya/sahl/sahl-advantage-current-account-banner-1726381198.jpg", "country_banner_title": "Financing Contratcs", "country_banner_subtitle": "Musharakah"}, {"id": "m3ar4dda", "type": "content_card", "enabled": true, "content_card_text": "Musharaka is derived from the word ‘sharikah’ which means ‘partnership’. Musharaka is defined as a partnership where profits are shared as per an agreed ratio whereas the losses are shared in proportion to the capital or investment of each partner. All partners must provide capital and may participate in management of business project.", "content_card_title": "Definition"}, {"id": "m3ar67io", "type": "content_card", "enabled": true, "content_card_text": "

It is a Partnership where one partner agrees to gradually purchase the units/stake of ownership of the other partner in a property/asset jointly acquired until full ownership of all units passes to him.

There are three components of DM contract:

  • Joint acquisition by the Bank and customer of asset or property.
  • The customer buys out the share of the Bank in the asset/property.
  • A customer as a lessee uses the share of the bank paying rentals to the bank (financier).
    • ", "content_card_title": "Diminishing Musharakah"}, {"id": "m3ar9ra0", "type": "content_card", "enabled": true, "content_card_text": "
  • DM is used for mortgage financing, asset-based financing such as motor vehicles, plant, and machinery.
  • Pricing is normally mirrored against conventional facilities.
  • The profit rate is variable and benchmarked against the bank’s base rate.
  • Unlike conventional loans there is no capitalization.
  • Profit is recognized on an accrual basis based on the outstanding principal amount.

    • Default penalties are charged but not recognized as income-given to charity.

    ", "content_card_title": "Features of Musharakah"}, {"id": "m3arcz9g", "type": "content_card", "enabled": true, "content_card_text": "

    Our customer takes an ABF of Kes.8m for a car costing Kes.10m. Two years later when he had repaid Kes 2m of the principal (therefore Kes.6m outstanding balance) the vehicle was involved in an accident and totally written off. Insurance compensation of Kes 7m was paid. Therefore, in the principal of PLS, proceed (insurance compensation) is shared: -.

    Bank: 60% * 7,000,000 = 4,200,000

    Customer: 40% * 7,000,000 = 2,800,000

    Note: The bank will be left with a residual balance of Kes 1.8 million which it will have to write off. If this was a conventional loan the bank would first make good its loan balance, so takes Kes.6m, and gives the balance Kes 1 million to the customer. Therefore, with Islamic finance the customer is better off with Kes 1.8m (2.8 - 1).

    Please note that in the above example, it is assumed the accident was not caused by the customer’s negligence/misconduct.

    ", "content_card_title": "Profit and Risk sharing: illustration for Musharaka"}, {"id": "m3arg5t7", "type": "content_card", "enabled": false, "content_card_text": "

    Note: The bank will be left with a residual balance of Kes 1.8 million which it will have to write off. If this was a conventional loan the bank would first make good its loan balance, so takes Kes.6m, and gives the balance Kes 1 million to the customer. Therefore, with Islamic finance the customer is better off with Kes 1.8m (2.8 - 1).

    Please note that in the above example, it is assumed the accident was not caused by the customer’s negligence/misconduct.

    ", "content_card_title": "Profit and Risk sharing: illustration for Musharaka"}], "footer": "footers/main_footer", "header": "headers/sahl", "parent": "1592", "updated_by": 15, "header_logo": "kenya/sahl-logo.jpg", "override_logo": true, "page_sections": null, "bottom_bar_nav": null}

Founded in 1993, KCB FC has risen to be a formidable football side playing in the top-tier league in Kenya, the FKF-premier league. Better known as the bankers, the team has produced some of the best football talents that this country boasts of. KCB FC is currently coached by gaffer Zedekiah ‘Zico’ Otieno and his assistant is Godfrey Oduor. The bankers came close to clinching their maiden Kenya Premier League title in the 2020/21 season finishing second with 3 points behind the league winners.


In the previous season 2019/21, the team was promoted from the second-tier division; Kenya Super League to the Kenya Premier League. KCB FC is known for its explosive attacking style of football. In the concluded season (2021/22) Striker, Derrick Otanga scooped the golden boot award and the team finished 7th garnering 49points. The bankers won Kenya Transparency Cup in 2004 and with the new additions in 2022 to an already star-studded squad, the 2022/23 season looks promising for the team.

Rally Sponsorship

KCB Bank Kenya, a synonymous name in the local motorsports scene has played a pivotal role in elevating the motorsports landscape in the country to unimaginable heights while giving a platform to local drivers to participate in regional, and international competitions.

When the Safari Rally was excluded from the WRC calendar in 2002, KCB stepped in to fill in the void by sponsoring the Kenya National Rally Championship (KNRC), Autocross and other local circuits spending a huge investment of KShs 1.7 billion in two decades. Since the return of the legendary event to the Kenyan soil in 2021, KCB has reaffirmed its commitment to the sport by injecting over KShs. 400 million while extending support to local rally drivers – Nikhil Sachania, Evans Kavisi and Karan Patel to participate in the global spectacle. In the 2024 edition, KCB pumped KShs. 194.5 million into the Safari Rally. Also, supported two drivers – African Rally Champion Karan Patel and Nikhil Sachania who raised the Kenyan flag high at the iconic event that saw thousands throng Naivasha for a once in a lifetime experience. Over and beyond the thrills of the cars, at the heart of the Safari Rally was proper waste management where KShs. 1 million was dedicated to this course. Additionally, we planted 2000 trees in various schools in line with the sustainable development goals as part of our larger corporate citizenship agenda to reduce the environmental impact of the sport.
